  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62411].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Currently, Site homage can be set to choose which app a user land when they log in. It's not possible to set this homepage for anonymous users. As an example, if a user has no access to JIRA and got anonymous access in Confluence. When the anonymous user accesses the instance the anonymous user will get JIRA and will be asked to log in. 

h3. Suggested Solution
There should be an option to set the landing page for anonymous users.
fields.summary: Ability to set the Homepage for Anonymous Users

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62404].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
When using the advanced JQL search function in Issue Navigator, fixVersions are not filtered based on the project you are searching against. Instead, a larger list of fixVerions is rendered. In addition, this fixVersion list will persist to render no matter what project you start your query with.

h3. Environment
Cloud - 1000.305.0
Server - Current

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open Issue Navigator 
# Click on Advanced to display the advanced JQL text box
# Use a query like: project = "replaceWithYourProjectKey" AND fixVersion = 
- Pay attention to the list of fixVersions listed
# Change the projectKey in your query to a different project

h3. Expected Results
The list of fixVersions should filter based on the project queried against

h3. Actual Results
The fixVersion list will list fixVersions in all projects
 
h3. Notes
The basic JQL query tool will filter fixVersions based on the project selected

h3.Workaround
Users can utilize the basic JQL query tool which will filter fixVersions based on the project that is selected
fields.summary: fixVersions are not filtered in the advanced JQL query tool based on the project selected

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62403].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
While trying to grant project permissions to users, some users without application access will appear in the list and admin will be able to grant these users any project permissions

h3. Suggested Solution
Just like inactive users, they should not appear in the user picker list when admin is searching for users to grant them permissions.
fields.summary: Do not allow users that are without application access to be granted with any permissions

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62400].
  {panel}

when installation Jira on premise as a standard installation (by unpacking the .zip, rpm, whatever) the underlying Tomcat is using JSESSIONID for his session cookies.
This leads to weird logout-situations when running multiple products (Jira, Confluence, etc.) on the same server.

*Suggestion:*
change the CookieName in the default context as suggested in your knowledgebase article in all downloadable packages:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/confkb/logging-into-another-atlassian-application-logs-me-out-of-confluence-268043930.html
fields.summary: Change default CookieName in standard installations
Allow mail to be created as JIRA issues under Default Reporter when sender granted Confluence application access only

h3. PROBLEM:

Currently, when clicking on a commit in an issue detail page in JIRA, there's an option for you to create a review for all the commits. However, same feature isn't possible for Branches. 

 
h3. SUGGESTION:

It would be great if the same functionality can be implemented for Branch.
fields.summary: Ability to Create a Review for a Branch in JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62397].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

In case that JIRA is integrated with external directories, remember-me token should be ignored when users managed in the directories log in JIRA at least.
The root need is that users can still log in after an administrator forces a password change (due to the remember-me token).

h3. Environment
 * JIRA 7.2.0
 * Crowd 2.9.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Integrate JIRA with Crowd
 # Log in JIRA with a user (User A) and then, check "Remember my login on this computer"
 # Restart the browser
 # Access JIRA with the same browser

h3. Expected Results

JIRA should show login page and need User A to input the credentials
h3. Actual Results

User A could log in without any authentication.
h3. Notes
 * The above actual results might cause some troubles in the following scenario{panel}_In case that there are some password leakages, an admin of the external directories wants the users to update their passwords immediately._
 # In the past, User A logged in JIRA with checking "Remember my login on this computer"
 # An admin of Crowd notices that a password of User A was leaked
 # The admin access Crowd, open user setting page of User A and set an attribute called "requiresPasswordChange" as "true" (It would require User A to update the password when the next login.)
 # In spite of the above setting, User A can log in JIRA without updating the password{panel}
* Confluence, Bitbucket Server and Bamboo behave as well at this moment

h3. Workaround

Disabling remember-me token is only the workaround.
fields.summary: When a password in an external directory is reset, Administrators should have an option to invalidate 'remember me' tokens

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62396].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

Unrestrict Conditions in Workflow to recognise various Field Input Type.

h3. Example

# Create Custom Field with Text Based
# Go Workflow > Condition
# Select "User Is In Custom Field"

h3. Actual Results

The Condition will not accept any Field other than "User Picker" type Input Field thus condition will not be met.


h3. Expectation

The Condition will accept any Field other than "User Picker" type Input Field hence condition will recognise.

h3. Workaround

Use "User Picker" Input Type Field OR that field that is recognised by Conditions.
fields.summary: Unrestrict Conditions in Workflow to recognise any Field Input Type

JIRA
Permissions General Overview
<https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/JIRA+Permissions+General+Overview?src=mail&src.mail.timestamp=1472570448441&src.mail.notification=com.atlassian.confluence.plugins.confluence-content-notifications-plugin%3Apage-edited-notification&src.mail.recipient=ff8081813fe690d5013fe88f358c016e&src.mail.action=view>
JIRA has a flexible security system which allows you to configure who can
access JIRA, and what they can do/see within JIRA. There are five types of
security within JIRA:
1. Global permissions
<https://confluence.atlassian.com/adminjiracloud/managing-global-permissions-776636359.html>
-
these apply to JIRA as a whole (e.g. who can log in).
2. Project permissions
<http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+Project+Permissions>
organised into permission schemes, these apply to projects as a whole
(e.g. who can see the project's issues ('Browse' permission), create, edit
and assign them).
3. Issue security levels
<http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Configuring+Issue-level+Security>-
organised into security schemes, these allow the visibility of individual
issues to be adjusted, within the bounds of the project's permissions.
4. Comment visibility
<http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Commenting+on+an+Issue> -
allows the visibility of individual comments (within an issue) to be
restricted.
5. Work-log visibility
<http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Logging+Work+on+an+Issue> -
allows the visibility of individual work-log entries (within an issue) to
be restricted. Does not restrict visibility of progress bar on issue time
tracking.
Different Projects, Different Permissions
Permission schemes allow you to apply varying access levels to combinations
of groups, roles and individuals on a per-project basis. A permission
scheme will enable/disable specific actions for users for that project. For
example, the 'Browse Project' permission for a particular project restricts
who can view the project in JIRA and thus view issues that belong to that
project via the Issue Navigator. Without this permission, user(s) would not
be able to access ('browse') that project.
You could have permission schemes applied per project that give certain
customer groups or roles access only to the project (via the 'Browse
Project' permission) that pertains to them, while giving the internal
groups or roles all permissions across multiple projects. See Managing
Project Permissions <http://confluence.atlassian.com/x/ZAISCw> for further
details.
Reusable Permission Schemes: Using Project Roles (default and recommended)
Each project has Project Roles associated with it: Project Lead,
Administrators, Developers, and Users. As you define your Permission
Scheme, you can assign permissions in your Permission Scheme to a Project
Role (e.g. Project Role (Users)). When you select the Permission Scheme for
a project, JIRA will grant the permissions specified in the scheme to the
specific users/groups that you've defined in the Project Roles for your
project.
This allows you to reuse the same Permission Scheme for different projects
that have the same security needs, but different groups. You then select
the same Permission Scheme for the Project, but Manage Project Role
Membership
<http://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRA/Managing+Project+Role+Membership>
to substitute different users/groups. Sharing a Permission Scheme also
facilitates the creation of Administrator groups across the projects

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62392].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Customers would like the ability within the Issue Navigator of JIRA to display the timestamp for date fields such as Created date.   Natively there is not a supported way to accomplish this within JIRA.  However there was a KB article created over at [Showing Extended Timestamp in the Created Column of the Issue Navigator|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAKB/Showing+Extended+Timestamp+in+the+Created+Column+of+the+Issue+Navigator], that explained a means to customize the file 'date-columnview.vm' directly to accomplish this.

The problem now is that those instructions no longer valid to JIRA 7.x versions.   Those instructions only appear to work for JIRA 6.4.x and before.  Presumably the code changes in JIRA 7 altered the way in which these .vm files are used to render the issue navigator results page.


h3. Suggested Solution
Allow JIRA administrators to customize the view of this issue navigator to include timestamps
OR
Provide an alternative work-around that might explain how this could be customized on a JIRA 7.x platform.
fields.summary: Showing Extended Timestamp in the Created Column of the Issue Navigator in JIRA 7

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62387].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
When changes are made to specific fields within a workflow, the only method of tracking these changes is by looking through the specific tickets history. It would be nice to be able to see changes made to a specific field within a given project by having a report available that does this.

h3. Environment
Cloud - Current
Server - Current

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Open an existing project
# Click on Reports

h3. Expected Results
A report that will allow you to view field changes is available

h3. Actual Results
There is currently no report that tracks field changes and total number of times the field has been changed
 
h3. Notes
A specific use case for this would be tracking changes made to a date field titled: Due Date
fields.summary: As a JIRA Administrator, I would like to be able to run a report that will show me changes made to specific fields with a given project.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62386].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

When a saved filter contains a project, which JQL has the project name or project key, and a user that don't have permission to view this project access this filter, the project name/key in the filter change to its database ID to all users accessing this filter. This breaks many functionalities that depend on this filter, like dashboard gadgets and also the the list of boards that appear under a project. 

h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a filter containing a project (or some projects), like project in (ABC, XYZ)
 # Save this filter sharing it publicly
 # Set another user to have permission to view projects ABC and XYZ
 # With this user click Issues > View all filters and search by the saved filter on #2 and open it
 # Set a third user not to have permission in one of the projects (ABC or XYZ)
 # With this third user click Issues > View all filters and search by the saved filter on #2 and open it
 # With the second user refresh the page showing the filter

h3. Expected Results

The filter shouldn't change the project name/key to ID for the users that have permission to view all projects in the filter
h3. Actual Results

The filter changes from project name/key to the project's database ID even for the users that have permission to view all projects in the filter
h3. Notes

This does not update the database entries for the filters. Restarting the JIRA Application will refresh the filter data back to the project names, temporarily until the filter is accessed again by someone without permissions.
h3. Workaround

Share the filter only with groups/users that have permission to view the projects in the filter
fields.summary: JIRA changes project name/key to database ID on a saved filter

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62385].
  {panel}

It would be very useful to have a quick jump list which allows the user to search and navigate directly to a project or board.

I would envision it functioning as follows:

# User presses `_q_` (or another appropriate shortcut)
# A searchable list much like the quick operations list appears allowing the user to filter to a board or project by typing it's name or a portion thereof.
# Pressing Enter or clicking on the item will jump the user to the board or project as appropriate.

An alternative way to access this would be via the project or board drop down menus, this would then allow the user to specifically search for boards or projects.
fields.summary: UI: Provide a quick project and board search

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62383].
  {panel}

In our pretty large organization, more and more teams use sprints and usually have their naming convention.

To setup the board, we mostly rely on components, but sometimes multiple components are used and, then the issue can be added in another team's sprint.
 This can "pollute" the team dashboard by showing other teams' sprints, sometimes also pollutes dashboards showing current sprint burndown, because their sprint comes first in priority.

The way I found so far is to exclude some components, but it's not an ideal solution, since those issues then completely disappear from the board, while not being worked on yet.

Similarly to components, where we have {{component in (componentsWithString(...))}}, I'd like to be able to filter the sprints by a given pattern, so that the query would look like this:
 {{project = ABC AND component = XYZ AND (Sprint is EMPTY or Sprint in (sprintsWithString("MySprintPattern - "))}}
* with pre-condition that all my sprints contain {{MySprintPattern - }} pattern, for instance \{\{MySprintPattern - 01}}, {{MySprintPattern - 02}}, etc.
* this basically means, once the issue of my component is assigned to another teams' sprint, then only the issue would disappear from my board
fields.summary: Add "sprintsWithString" JQL function to be able to filter sprints by their name

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62380].
  {panel}

We often have the case to see which tasks are assigned to a specific user to determine what he or she can do next. 

It would be really comfortable to just click on his icon and the filter will be changed:
atlassian.net/secure/RapidBoard.jspa?projectKey=XYZ&rapidView=78&view=planning

I think this does not take too much effort and can be really useful
fields.summary: Filter by User on RapidBoard

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62371].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
When viewing the sub-task type in its parent issue view screen, you are only able to differentiate by its icons, and not the issue type name.

h3. Suggested Solution
To be able to display the Sub-task Issue Type Name as well beside the icon. 

h3. Workaround 
# Create a new Custom Field(Issue Type) for your sub-tasks. Obtain the ID for this custom field.
# Follow the [guide|https://confluence.atlassian.com/jira/how-to-display-custom-field-of-the-sub-task-in-the-parent-issue-screen-163939652.html] however the order for below step is changed.(Where xxxxx the the id of your custom field.)
|customfield_xxxxx, issuetype, status, assignee, progress| 
# Once you have done the above, you would be able see that this custom field will appear in the order before the icon.
# You will need to make a copy of the existing workflow(if the workflow is shared by other different projects) to make it unique for sub-tasks only. You will also need the plugin [Suite Utilities for JIRA|https://marketplace.atlassian.com/plugins/com.googlecode.jira-suite-utilities/cloud/overview].
# In the new workflow, locate the transition from *Create Issue* to *Open*. In this transition, add a new post-function *'Copy Field value from other Field'*.
!screenshot-3.png|thumbnail!
# For Source Field, select *Issue Type* while for Destination Field, select the *Custom Field* that you have created for the sub task. For option, choose 'Copy withing same issue' and add the post-function.
# Once all the above is done, each time you create a sub-task, the post function will copy the value of the Issue Type Name and copy it into the new custom Field which will now then appear in your sub task list in its parents issue view screen.
fields.summary: Display Issue Subtask Type Name in Parent Issue View Screen.

  {panel}

h3. Summary
At the moment, users can be given group memberships through nested groups. This may make it hard to track exactly how/why certain users are given permissions to certain projects/etc. 

This is even more critical when the permission in question is permission to access JIRA. If nested groups causes the user count to exceed the license, JIRA will not be usable

h3. Suggestion
Make nested group memberships easier to be identified, especially if they affect the entire instance (eg. application access, etc)
fields.summary: Make Nested Groups memberships easily identifiable

  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

When using a Select List (cascading) type field with a high number of options, it takes couple of seconds for all these options to be loaded for the dropdown menu, causing a delay when opening the Create window.

h3. Suggested Solution
 
Add a auto-complete renderer for fields of the Select List (cascading) type to avoid all options from being loaded when creating a new issue. This will also help users when looking for specific values, as they won't need to scroll through a high number of options to find the desired value.
fields.summary: Select List (cascading) Auto-Complete

h3. Summary

Export to Excel CSV is not displaying full name of users in file.

h3. Environment

* JIRA Version 1000.285.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Log into JIA Cloud instance
# Issues > Search for issues
# Make sure either Assignee or Reporter is field is being displayed

  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62365].
  {panel}

It would be quite helpful if we could have additional configuration options for filters and their subscriptions.

Some examples of such confirguration options might be:
* Description/Notes -- Customizable note/description for the administrator to populate which could include links to Confluence KB
* From Name -- From email can remain the same, but possibly have a different name
* Email Header: Importance -- High/Default/Low -- https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4021#page-32
* HTML Background (eg. change background color based on the filter)

The reason is when a large number of them are open, additional options to help differentiate one from another is extremely helpful. 

For subscriptions, I know I can do so at the rule level within my mail client, but that doesn't help the remaining members of the team when they received dozens of subscriptions.

Thanks!
fields.summary: Provide more customization for filters & subscriptions such as notes, 'from, importance, etc.

Our team manages deployments for all our cloud customers. As such, I'm marking this request for improved platform support as invalid.

We have a related Jira Server ticket for this issue, see linked issues and watch that for updates on our [Jira Server and Data Center products here|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62362].

Thanks!

Steve King
Product Manager
  {panel}

h3. PROBLEM:

Currently, Atlassian applications are using a variety of recommended database collation when using MSSQL server.
 # Confluence - SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CS_AS
 # BitBucket - SQL_Latin1_General_CP1_CS_AS
 # FishEye - Latin1_General_CS_AS
 #  JIRA - SQL_Latin1_General_CP437_CI_AI or Latin1_General_CI_AI

 
h3. h3. SUGGESTION:

To have a standardized/uniformed database collation for all Atlassian applications when using SQL server.
fields.summary: Standardized the Recommended MS SQL Collation for all Atlassian applications

JiraUserAvatarProvider.getAvatar(final String email, final int size) called userManager.getUsers() so that it could iterate through all of them to find a matching email address.

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62351].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

If a transition (using generic event) is not configured to send email, however, a user adds a comment on the transition screen (IssueCommented event configured to send email), then the IssueCommented event does not send an email as well. JIRA doesn't generate IssueCommented event, so the user does not receive an email for this comment.

 
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Configure a workflow transition with post function to fire Generic event.
 # Make sure to edit notification scheme so that Generic event does not send email
 # Make sure to edit notification scheme so that IssueCommented event sends email
 # Create an issue
 # Transition the issue and add a comment on the transition screen

h3. Expected Results

Use should receive an email for the IssueCommented event
h3. Actual Results

No email is received for this comment.

There is nothing written in the atlassian-jira-outgoing-mail.log
h3. Notes
As a user, a comment added during a transition or on the view issues screen directly, is the same. They appear the same way on the issue. So, they should be treated the same way too.

h3. Workaround

Currently there is no workaround for this.
fields.summary: Adding a comment in a transition screen where transition does not send email does not send email for the IssueCommented event as well

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62346].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

Currently, the issue collector delivers a fragment of HTML/JS to embed in the client website that interacts with JIRA via a URL that encodes state in it. 

Following on, the client browser will cache the content and a (potentially) outdated resource will be used by the client browser when JIRA or its plugins are upgraded. 

This is worsened by the fact that products such as Confluence, Portfolio and Stash are hardcoding these URLs (currently pointing to JAC) in the actual source of these products and are basically using these URLs as "API" :(

h3. Steps to Reproduce.

1. Create an issue collector in JIRA.
2. Get the html fragment for the issue collector and embed it into a html page.
3. Visit the the html page and use the collector so that the browser caches the content.
4. Make a change to JIRA source such that the content delivered for the URL included in the html fragment provided by the collector is different.
5. Restart JIRA.
6. Visit the external html page and try to use the collector again.

h3. Actual Results
* The content retrieved from the URL by the embedded collector is out of date and does not reflect the changes done in step 4.

h3. Expected Results
* The content retrieved from the URL by the embedded collector is up to date and reflects the changes done in step 4.

h3. Workaround

Clear the browser cache to obtain the new content.
fields.summary: Issue collector URLs should deliver the most recent JS/HTML for the version of JIRA hosting the collector

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62338].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
When you disabled keyboard shortcuts in your user profile and perform certain actions, then keyboard shortcuts would work although disabled. Most keyboard shortcuts are relatively harmless because they prompt before doing anything. However, some just go off and do stuff without prompting, eg. 'i' for Assign to Me. This makes them dangerous.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Disable keyboard shortcuts in your profile.
# Open a ticket or hard-refresh the browser page if it's already open.
# Type a keyboard shortcut and verify it doesn't work (eg. 'c' for the Create Ticket window or '?' for help).
# Do an action that creates a modal popup dialog, eg:
#* Click on the "Create" in the Jira header, then click Cancel. (Reproducible only in JIRA 7.2.0)
#* click on the thumbnail of the attached image. Once the image is displayed, click on the X in the top right corner to dismiss it. (Reproducible in both JIRA 7.2.0 and JIRA 6.3.15)
# Type a keyboard shortcut, eg. 'c' or '?'. The keyboard shortcut will work and the window will pop up.

h3. Expected Results
The Keyboard shortcuts do not work as the Keyboard Shortcut is disabled in the User profile.  

h3. Actual Results
The Keyboard shortcuts do work. 
 
h3. Notes
* Previewing the attachment and close it back, will trigger the keyboard shortcut to be enabled.
* Hard Refresh would make the shortcuts not work again
* Most keyboard shortcuts are relatively harmless because they prompt before doing anything. However, some just go off and do stuff without prompting, eg. 'i' for Assign to Me. This makes them dangerous.
fields.summary: Even if "Disable Keyboard shortcuts" is set, certain actions can trigger then back

  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

Users may wish to include Timezone functionality into their Date/Time picker custom fields. By default, this isn't possible, so the user may proceed to configure the following formats in JIRA's *Administration >> System >> Advanced Settings*:
 * jira.date.time.picker.java.format
 ** Add 'z' to the format
 * jira.date.time.picker.javascript.format
 ** Add '%Z' to the format

!Timezone_Format.png|width=194,height=35,thumbnail!

This does allow the timezone to be shown in issue view and in the issue navigator for example. However, when the changes above are done and the Calendar selector is used to specify the custom field's value, the calendar cannot add the timezone on it's own and the user must manually type in the timezone.

!Calendar_No_Timezone.png|thumbnail!
h3. Suggested Solution

Change/Extend the calendar selector to be able to accommodate timezone selection.
h3. Workaround

Manually type in the timezone for every entry; or, do not add timezones to the formats above.
fields.summary: Add timezone compatibility to the Date/Time Picker calendar selector

It is not mentioned anywhere in the REST API documentation that, when using Oauth to authenticate REST calls, the Oauth data has to be in the request header and not in the body.

This needs to be documented because putting the Oauth data in the request body works for some endpoints but not with all of them and this is causing confusion.

Below example page is not mentioning anything similar:
 - [JIRA REST API Example OAuth authentication|https://developer.atlassian.com/display/JIRADEV/JIRA+REST+API+Example+-+OAuth+authentication]
fields.summary: It should be documented that, when using Oauth to authenticate REST calls, the Oauth data has to be put in the request header, not in the body

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62310].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
# It is currently not possible to allow issue types of a certain type to be resolved if there is a review
# We have  multiple issue types, some of which will never need a crucible review and others that we need to ensure do have a review.

h3. Suggested Solution
# Introduce a validator/condition on a workflow transition  to check if there is a review for issues of a selected type.
# For example in one project we have 'Story' and 'Bug' issue types and would expect that there is a review for any 'Story' however as a 'Bug' is an investigation that wouldn't require any code changes we would not need a review on these.
# For a 'Story' to then be put into a completed status it must have a review in Crucible (possibly also validating that is is a closed review).
fields.summary: Workflow validation for issue types

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62309].
  {panel}

h3. Steps to reproduce
# Create a user with username *user1* and email _user1@email.com_ in LDAP
# Connect JIRA to LDAP
# Users will be given the _jira-users_ group membership upon first log in which grants them access to JIRA (without it the user can't access JIRA)
# Issue collector is created with _Match reporter_ set to *Attempt to match user session of submitter or submitter email address*
# Do *not* log in to JIRA with this user yet to ensure that the user doesn't have access to JIRA
# Create an issue via the issue collector, entering _user1@email.com_ in the email field

h3. Actual Results
# The issue will fail to be created with the following error message
{quote}*Oops! Something went wrong...*
Sorry, you can't create any issues right now, as you need to have access to a JIRA application to be able to create issues. To gain application access you need to be a member of a group assigned to an application.
Don't worry though! We've logged this problem and will look into it soon!{quote}

This is expected because 
# The issue collector will find a user associated to the email address
# It finds the user *user1* and attempts to create the issue using this user
# It finds that the user doesn't have access to JIRA (since the user has not logged in before)
# Issue creation will fail

h3. Suggestion
Allow the Issue Collector to act as a Log In so this user is given the _jira-users_ group membership and the issue is successfully created
fields.summary: Allow Issue Collector to act as "log in" and grant the permissions to access JIRA to successfully create issue

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62308].
  {panel}

h2. *Issue Summary*

When a user imports an issue into JIRA 7.1.X, he or she is named as the issue creator while the reporter of the issue originally is marked as the reporter.

The above causes a lot of confusion when the user looks at the issues history and sees the importer mentioned as the creator while marking he created the issue a long time ago rather than the day the issue was imported.
h2. *Steps to Reproduce*
 # Create a new JSON or CSV file that matches requirements JIRA expects.

{code:java}
IssueType, Summary, FixVersion, FixVersion, FixVersion, Component, Component, Issue ID, Parent ID, Reporter
Bug, "First issue", v1, , , Component1, , 1, , jbloggs
Bug, "Second issue", v2, , , Component1, Component2, 2, , fferdinando
Bug, "Third issue", v1, v2, v3, Component1, , 3, , fferdinando
Sub-task, "Fourth issue", v1, v2, , Component2, , , 2, jbloggs
{code}

 # Import the file to the target JIRA instance via external system import.
 # On completion, access the issue imported via the Issue Navigator page.
 # Go to history tab.

h2. *Expected Result*

JIRA does not show the importer as the issue creator especially not specifying the create date as actual date issue was created if it was specified in the CSV.
h2. *Actual Result*

JIRA shows the importer as the issue creator and specifies the created date as the date issue was originally created if it was specified in the CSV.
fields.summary: JIRA shows Issue Importer as Creator
Setup administrator account fails in JIRA with Oracle

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

h3. Summary

Can't set "Start date" and "Release date" in a version when using Japanese.
I couldn't reproduce this problem with any other language even if the language contains multi-byte characters (like Korean, French).

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set your language to Japanese in User Profile
# Go to *プロジェクト管理 > バージョン* page (*Project setting > Versions* page)
# Put a version name and click a calendar button
# Select a date in a dialog
 !calendar.png|thumbnail! 

h3. Expected Results
We can set "Start date" and "Release date" correctly.

h3. Actual Results
The following error was shown.
 !date_format_error.png|thumbnail! 
 
h3. Notes
* As I mentioned above, this problem doesn't occur with other languages than Japanese
* Even if I set the date manually (put the date in "d/MMM/yy" format), the error persists
* I could also reproduce this problem on *Board > Release* page
* It seems to be similar to JRA-61665 but different problem

h3.Workaround
Change user's language to English and set the dates and turn the language back to the original one.
fields.summary: Can't set "Start date" and "Release date" in a version when using Japanese

{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}

  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

When the transition fails, the input value for issue linked field will get cleared. But fields such as Comment, Label and etc., the values are stored on the screen. For more information on this behaviour, please review this video recording: {{[http://screencast.com/t/O3Lnx0yYM]}}.
 In the video, the *Due Date* is made to be required so that the transition will fail. As we can see from the video after the transition failed, the Linked Issue field got cleared but Cascading Field values and Comment Field value did not.
h3. Suggested Solution

Maintain the linked issues value even the transition fails.
fields.summary: Maintain the linked issues values when the workflow transition fails

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62300].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Currently, it is not possible for a user to keep a field from being visible until a certain part of the workflow if that field has a default value. Some users might want a field to appear later in the workflow of an issue but might want it to have a default value when appearing on a custom screen for users. For that field to be visible however, it has to be included in the 'View Issue' operation. Since the field will already have a value set, it will always be present, even if the field does not yet apply.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Set a default value for a field
# Create a custom screen for a workflow operation in the life of a ticket, and add this field to that screen
# Add the field to the view issue screen
# That field will appear from the creation of the ticket and will stay as long as a value is in place. This might not suite a user's needs if the user wants the field to apply to the custom screen in the workflow but not be present until then.

h3. Expected Results

h3. Actual Results
The field is set to the default value but only appears once applicable (using a custom screen for a workflow operation).

h3. Notes
The field will always be present.

h3.Workaround
Using a post function to SET the value after a workflow operation would work, but in the above scenario, a user would want the default value to be present in the screen so the field could be modified or changed before completing the operation.
fields.summary: Field Default Value causes value to always be present.

  {panel}

h4. Summary
Assign issue post function (for create issue) triggers issue assigned notification in JIRA 7

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Under post function for create issue action > Add *Assign issue to reporter* in workflow's post function (place it before *Fire a XXXX event that can be processed by the listeners* post function)
# Create issue

h4. Expected Result
JIRA will send notification only for event being fired. This is how it works in JIRA 4.x, JIRA 5.x, and JIRA 6.x.

h4. Actual Result
JIRA will send notification for Issue assigned event and the fired event

h4. Workaround
Place *assign issue to reporter* post function after *Fire a XXXX event that can be processed by the listeners*
fields.summary: Assign issue post function (for create issue) triggers issue assigned notification in JIRA 7

Now I have this pop up reminder for HipChat which I don't even use annoying the living shit out of me!

"HipChat Integration is out of date
Update to take full advantage of the latest features.
Update Now!"

Seriously, you cannot continue to abuse this overlay. I understand how it's a useful tool for communicating critical updates...ONCE or a few times, but NOT marketing and NOT forcing it down our throats every single time - this is literally driving me NUTS.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62262].
  {panel}

In order to make Logging Work easier and more accurate, I would like to suggest that when a user enters a value into the *Time Spent* field of the *Log Work* modal, that the *Date Started* field would automatically decrease by the amount of *Time Spent*.

This seems like a good default behavior to me because, my usual use case is:
 # I click on *Fix in Progress* and I write down what time I started working on the JIRA ticket on my notepad.
 # Then, when I am done working on the ticket or I switch to another task, I write down in my notepad what time I stopped working on the ticket.
 # I go back to *JIRA* and I click on *Log Work*.
 # In the *Log Work* modal I enter the *Time Spent* by figuring out how much time elapsed between the time I started working on the ticket and the time I stopped.
 # Then I always have to change the *Date Started* because it is always set to the current time and date by default, and there is NEVER a situation where that is the right value. If *Time Spent* was 15 minutes and the current date and time is _August 17, 2016 *4:00*PM_ then the actual *Date Started* has to be at least 15 minutes earlier than the current date and time, so _August 17, 2016 *3:45*PM_ would be a realistic value.
fields.summary: Adjust 'Date Started' Based Upon 'Time Spent' in the 'Log Work' Modal
Ability to specify different status to represent "RESOLVED"

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62260].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Customer has received following warnings when creating the tables in a MS SQL DB with the correct collation.
{code}
Warning! The maximum key length is 900 bytes. The index 'idx_group_attr_dir_name_lval' has maximum length of 1029 bytes. For some combination of large values, the insert/update operation will fail.
Warning! The maximum key length is 900 bytes. The index 'uk_group_attr_name_lval' has maximum length of 1029 bytes. For some combination of large values, the insert/update operation will fail.
Warning! The maximum key length is 900 bytes. The index 'idx_mem_dir_parent_child' has maximum length of 1149 bytes. For some combination of large values, the insert/update operation will fail.
Warning! The maximum key length is 900 bytes. The index 'idx_user_attr_dir_name_lval' has maximum length of 1029 bytes. For some combination of large values, the insert/update operation will fail.
Warning! The maximum key length is 900 bytes. The index 'entpropindexdoc_module' has maximum length of 1020 bytes. For some combination of large values, the insert/update operation will fail.
Warning! The maximum key length is 900 bytes. The index 'licenserolegroup_index' has maximum length of 1020 bytes. For some combination of large values, the insert/update operation will fail.
Warning! The maximum key length is 900 bytes. The index 'managedconfigitem_id_type_idx' has maximum length of 1020 bytes. For some combination of large values, the insert/update operation will fail.
{code}
The problem is that the nvarchar type will take two times the actual length of data entered + 2 bytes (see [MS KB|https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms186939.aspx]) which will take 255*2+2=512 bytes for each column and if the index contains more than one nvarchar column then warning message is thrown.

h2. Suggested Solution
In reality it's relatively rare to reach the limit in order for the index to fail. However it would be nice if we can limit the column length at first place.
fields.summary: Some indexes in JIRA have a maximum value bigger than 900 bytes which is not recommend in MS SQL Server.

h3. Cause
A service required for displaying the issue information is unavailable.
The cause for the service being unavailable is still under investigation.

h3. Workaround
 * Restart JIRA

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62251].
  {panel}

h3. Summary
Epic Link is not correctly set on issues imported through CSV.

h3. Environment
* JIRA v1000.253.1

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an Epic {code}Epic name: Epic1{code}
# Import issues through CSV {code}Summary,Epic Link
Test issue, Epic1{code}

h3. Expected Results
Issue imported should have an Epic linked

h3. Actual Results
The import is done without errors but Epic link field is blank
 
h3. Notes


h3. Partial Workaround

If you don't have many epics, you can bulk edit the issue, one search per epic. For example, if you have these epics with these stories:
* Epic: ABC-1: Epic Name: My Epic 1
** Story in Epic ABC-1: ABC-2, Epic Link: My Epic 1
** Story in Epic ABC-1: ABC-3, Epic Link: My Epic 1
* Epic ABC-4: Epic Name: My Epic 2
** Story in Epic ABC-4: ABC-5, Epic Link: My Epic 2

It's possible to:
# Import the 'Epic Name' to 'Epic Name', as expected
# Create a new text field (My Epic Link)
# Import 'Epic Link' to this text field (My Epic Link)
# For each Epic, search for stories with the Epic Link, for example
{code}
'My Epic Link' = 'My Epic 1'
{code}
# Bulk edit it to change the 'Epic Link' to 'My Epic 1'
fields.summary: Import epic link through CSV is no longer working

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Cloud*. Using *JIRA Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRASERVER-62250].
  {panel}

h3. Summary

Issue collector not loading/appear when user has no access to JIRA but has Confluence (as example) Access.
h3. Environment

Instance must have JIRA and CONFLUENCE installed and an issue collector being used. (Tests were made in cloud environment)
Also, this HTML embedded code bed can be used for testing [http://www.csgnetwork.com/htmlcodetest.html]
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create an issue collector
 # Assign a proper default reporter
 # Create a user limited to access confluence only (must not be allowed to access JIRA and)
 # Log in to JIRA as that user (either logging out and entering that user credentials or using the log "in as user" feature)
 # Paste the Issue Collector html code in the test site i.e: [http://www.csgnetwork.com/htmlcodetest.html] and test it.
h3. Expected Results


Should be able to open an issue normally using the collector.
h3. Actual Results

When using the "log in as user" feature, it shows the issue collector tab, but won't load (stuck on loading wheel). When entering user credentials in confluence, then trying to test the issue collector, the collector tab won't show.

\{noformat}
...
\{noformat}
 
h3. Notes

Took a deep check and couldn't find any related bug.
h3. Workaround

Log out from Atlassian applications before using it, or use access with incognito mode.
fields.summary: Issue collector not loading/appear when user has no access to JIRA but has Confluence Access
